aiAnalysis.summary: AFJ Limited's staging environment demonstrates strong foundational security with proper authentication controls and HTTPS implementation, but suffers from significant deficiencies in HTTP security headers across all scanned pages. All five admin API endpoints correctly return 403 status codes, indicating proper access controls are in place. However, critical security headers are missing from public-facing pages, leaving the application vulnerable to clickjacking, MIME-type sniffing, and cross-site scripting attacks. The absence of Content Security Policy (CSP) and Strict-Transport-Security (HSTS) headers represents the most pressing concern, as these provide essential defense-in-depth protections.
recommendations: Immediately implement X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff header across all pages to prevent MIME-type sniffing attacks
Add X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN to all pages (currently only present on /admin) to prevent clickjacking; use DENY if embedding is not required
Deploy Strict-Transport-Security header with appropriate max-age (e.g., max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains) to enforce HTTPS and prevent downgrade attacks
Implement a strict Content-Security-Policy header tailored to application requirements, starting with default-src 'self' and progressively opening only necessary directives
Add Referrer-Policy: strict-origin-when-cross-origin to protect user privacy and prevent information leakage
Include Permissions-Policy header to restrict browser features and APIs (geolocation, microphone, camera, etc.) that the application doesn't require
Conduct a full security header audit across the production environment to ensure parity with staging improvements
Implement automated security header validation in CI/CD pipeline to prevent regression
